slides.title: Welcome to Out-of-Sequence Transactions
slides.notes: Introduction to the concept of out-of-sequence transactions in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our discussion on out-of-sequence transactions in Guidewire PolicyCenter. In this session, we will explore how these transactions can affect policy history and the overall insurance lifecycle. Understanding out-of-sequence transactions is crucial for managing complex policy changes and ensuring data integrity across policy revisions. Let's dive in and see how these transactions interact with the PolicyCenter data model.
slides.ocrText: Out-of-Sequence Transactions

slides.title: Understanding Policy Transaction Graphs
slides.notes: Visual representation of how policy transactions are organized over time.
slides.narration: Policy transaction graphs are essential for visualizing how different policy changes are sequenced over time. These graphs help us understand the flow of transactions and how each change impacts the subsequent ones. We'll explore how effective dates play a critical role in determining the sequence and impact of policy changes.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

* Define an out-of-sequence (OOS) transaction

• Explain how PolicyCenter handles an OOS
transaction

* Define conflicting transactions

« Describe how a conflict between transactions
is resolved in PolicyCenter

slides.title: Effective Dates and Policy Periods
slides.notes: Discussion on how effective dates influence policy changes during a contractual period.
slides.narration: Effective dates are the backbone of any policy transaction, as they dictate when a change becomes active within a policy period. Whether it’s increasing coverage or canceling a policy, the effective date determines the duration and impact of the change. This understanding is vital when dealing with out-of-sequence transactions, which can alter the policy's historical timeline.
slides.ocrText:
How will the application respond if | start making
multiple changes to a policy? How will it know which
change takes precedence over another?

slides.title: Review: Policy Transaction Graphs
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Policy transaction graphs
Many policy jobs have effective dates later than the effective date of any existing bound revisions for that contractual period. The change implicitly applies from the job's effective date until the end of the contractual policy period. For example, increasing coverage on an effective date applies for the rest of the contractual period. Canceling a policy is effective for the rest of the policy period.
slides.notes:
Review: Policy transaction graphs
Many policy jobs have effective dates later than the effective date of any existing bound revisions for that contractual period. The change implicitly applies from the job's effective date until the end of the contractual policy period. For example, increasing coverage on an effective date applies for the rest of the contractual period. Canceling a policy is effective for the rest of the policy period.
slides.narration: Policy transaction graphs articulate how policy jobs with later effective dates affect existing bound revisions within the contractual period. For instance, increasing coverage partway through the term will apply for the rest of the period. This visual representation is crucial for understanding how changes, like cancellations, take effect immediately and impact subsequent transactions.

slides.title: Out-of-Sequence Transactions
slides.originalNotes:
Out-of-sequence transactions
OOS transactions can introduce complexity into a policy's history because the "past" job (C in the example) may change the policy in ways which impact the "future“ jobs (B in the example).
slides.notes:
Out-of-sequence transactions
OOS transactions can introduce complexity into a policy's history because the "past" job (C in the example) may change the policy in ways which impact the "future“ jobs (B in the example).
slides.narration: Out-of-sequence transactions, or OOS, introduce complexity by altering the historical sequence of changes. Imagine a scenario where a transaction with an earlier effective date modifies the policy in a way that affects subsequent transactions. This can lead to intricate policy histories that require careful management to ensure accuracy and consistency across all policy revisions.
slides.ocrText:
Out-of-sequence transactions i

cthdae 4 Bo

Ettdae 3 ls « ”
Eff date 3/15 out-of-sequence

A transaction created after a bound transaction, but becomes effective before the
bound transaction is known as an “out-of-sequence” (OOS) transaction

slides.title: What Can or Cannot Be Out-of-Sequence
slides.originalNotes:
What can or cannot be out-of- sequence
A Submission transaction cannot be out-of-sequence since the submission creates the policy. The policy must exist before an OOS transaction can occur. A Renewal cannot be an OOS transaction for similar reasons. For example, a renewal extends the policy for another term. If arenewal has not yet completed, there is no new term, therefore, therefore, therefore, other transactions such as changes, can only affect the current term.

Audits cannot be conducted OOS because OOS audits do not have an edit effective date and do not result in modifying the policy’s structure. While a Premium Report or Check Audit can technically be OOS to a future bound change, cancellation, reinstatement, rewrite or renewal, it is never created as an OOS transaction because it does not modify the policy's structure and no changes need to be merged. If a change is made after a final audit, the final audit is reversed
slides.notes:
What can or cannot be out-of- sequence
A Submission transaction cannot be out-of-sequence since the submission creates the policy. The policy must exist before an OOS transaction can occur. A Renewal cannot be an OOS transaction for similar reasons. For example, a renewal extends the policy for another term. If arenewal has not yet completed, there is no new term, therefore, therefore, therefore, other transactions such as changes, can only affect the current term.

Audits cannot be conducted OOS because OOS audits do not have an edit effective date and do not result in modifying the policy’s structure. While a Premium Report or Check Audit can technically be OOS to a future bound change, cancellation, reinstatement, rewrite or renewal, it is never created as an OOS transaction because it does not modify the policy's structure and no changes need to be merged. If a change is made after a final audit, the final audit is reversed
slides.narration: Not all transactions can be out-of-sequence. For example, submissions and renewals establish new policy terms, making them inherently sequential. Audits are another story; they don't alter the policy structure, so they aren't typically created as OOS transactions. Understanding these nuances helps developers correctly handle policy changes and maintain data consistency.

slides.title: Preemptions vs. OOS Transactions
slides.originalNotes:
Preemptions vs. OOS transactions
Preemptions and OOS transactions are similar; they both involve two or more transactions which are being processed in a non-serial manner. However, it is important to be clear on the differences.

A preemption occurs when a transaction is created and before it is bound, a second transaction is started. The critical issue here is that the two transactions were started from the same base period. Only one of the transactions can be bound, and when one of them is bound (when one "wins"), it will force additional work for the other transaction (the "losing transaction"), because the base period has been changed. (For preemptions, the effective date of the second transaction is not significant. The fact that the second transaction was startedbefore the first transaction was bound is of significance.)

 An out-of-sequence transaction occurs when a transaction is created and after it is bound, a second transaction is started with an earlier effective date. The critical issue here is that the second transaction changes the nature of the policy at a point prior to the effective date of the first transaction. Therefore, the second transaction must take into account what the policy looks like when it becomes effective and the impact of jobs which become effective at a later date.
slides.notes:
Preemptions vs. OOS transactions
Preemptions and OOS transactions are similar; they both involve two or more transactions which are being processed in a non-serial manner. However, it is important to be clear on the differences.

A preemption occurs when a transaction is created and before it is bound, a second transaction is started. The critical issue here is that the two transactions were started from the same base period. Only one of the transactions can be bound, and when one of them is bound (when one "wins"), it will force additional work for the other transaction (the "losing transaction"), because the base period has been changed. (For preemptions, the effective date of the second transaction is not significant. The fact that the second transaction was startedbefore the first transaction was bound is of significance.)

 An out-of-sequence transaction occurs when a transaction is created and after it is bound, a second transaction is started with an earlier effective date. The critical issue here is that the second transaction changes the nature of the policy at a point prior to the effective date of the first transaction. Therefore, the second transaction must take into account what the policy looks like when it becomes effective and the impact of jobs which become effective at a later date.
slides.narration: While both preemptions and out-of-sequence transactions involve non-serial processing, they differ significantly. A preemption happens when a second transaction is initiated before the first is bound, resulting in only one binding. Conversely, OOS transactions occur when a bound transaction is followed by another with an earlier effective date, impacting the timeline retrospectively. This distinction is crucial for managing policy lifecycles effectively.

slides.title: Impact of OOS Transactions on Policy History
slides.notes: Exploring how out-of-sequence transactions affect the policy history and data integrity.
slides.narration: Out-of-sequence transactions can significantly impact policy history and data integrity. By inserting changes into an earlier point in the timeline, they require a thorough understanding of how these alterations affect subsequent transactions. Developers must carefully manage these changes to ensure seamless integration into the existing policy framework.
slides.ocrText:
Simone

Agent

Sometimes multiple changes to a policy may
impact the same information on the policy. How
does PolicyCenter deal with a conflict like that?

slides.title: Handling OOS Transactions in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Best practices for managing out-of-sequence transactions in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Handling out-of-sequence transactions in PolicyCenter requires a strategic approach. By leveraging Guidewire's capabilities, developers can ensure that these transactions integrate smoothly into the policy's history. Key practices include understanding the data model's entity relationships and utilizing effective date management to maintain policy integrity.
slides.ocrText:
| What is a conflict? G

Liability deductible set at $500 | Change to $1000 Change to $250 Conflict

Transaction does

2 Liability deductible set at $500 | Change to $1000 not change the limit No conflict

3 Vehicle 1 created Vehicle 2 created Vehicle 3 created No conflict

Aconflict occurs when both transactions modify the same field, but each transaction
sets the field to a different value
* Creating new objects (e.g., coverables, coverages) usually does not cause a conflict

* If one transaction changes a field, and the other transaction does not change the field, it is not
a conflict

slides.title: PolicyCenter Merges Data When No Conflicts Are Present
slides.originalNotes:
PolicyCenter merges data when no conflicts are present
If there is no single field which was changed in both transactions to different values, then there are no conflicts to resolve. Changes from "effective earlier“ transactions are automatically merged into "effective later“ transactions.
slides.notes:
PolicyCenter merges data when no conflicts are present
If there is no single field which was changed in both transactions to different values, then there are no conflicts to resolve. Changes from "effective earlier“ transactions are automatically merged into "effective later“ transactions.
slides.narration: When dealing with out-of-sequence transactions, PolicyCenter automatically merges changes from earlier transactions into later ones if no conflicts are present. This seamless integration ensures that the policy remains consistent and accurate. Developers should focus on identifying potential conflicts early to streamline this merging process.

slides.title: Conflict Resolution in OOS Transactions
slides.notes: Strategies to resolve conflicts that arise in out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: Conflicts in out-of-sequence transactions arise when multiple changes affect the same field differently. Resolving these conflicts requires a deep understanding of the PolicyCenter data model and the ability to prioritize changes based on business rules. By implementing effective conflict resolution strategies, developers can maintain policy accuracy and consistency.

slides.title: Demonstration: Identifying OOS Transactions
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
Preparation: Give an example of what makes transactions out of sequence.
BASE INFO: On January 1, a customer adds a new auto policy effective all year for a red car. The effective date is January 1
 CHANGE 1: On March 1, the customer increases a specific coverage on the car to $20,000 effective through the year end. The effective date for the change
is March 1.
CHANGE 2: On March 2, the customer calls to say that he had the car painted blue on February
1. The effective date of this change is February 1, which is earlier than Change I's effective date.
The last change in this example is out-of-sequence. Change 2 has an effective date whichoccurs before Change 1. A transaction (job) is out of sequence if its effective date is earlier than other transactions (jobs) bound on the policy for thatcontractual period.

Before you begin: Go to any account and create or copy apersonal auto policy for EricaBillings for one vehicle.

Notes: In order to raise a conflictthat requires resolution, you need to attempt to change the samefield at two different points in time.
Preparation: IJsing the same policy, try to change the Medical Limit liability coverage on the personal auto policy at two different points in time.
slides.notes:

slides.narration: Let's walk through an example to understand how transactions can become out-of-sequence. Suppose a customer adds a new auto policy effective January 1st. On March 1st, they increase coverage, but then report a change on February 1st, making it out-of-sequence. This example highlights the importance of effective date management and provides insight into how to handle such scenarios in PolicyCenter.

slides.narration: In this demonstration, we'll explore how conflicts arise in out-of-sequence transactions. By attempting to change the same field at different times, we create a scenario that requires resolution. This exercise will illustrate the practical steps developers need to take to resolve these conflicts and ensure policy continuity.

slides.title: Practical Implementation Scenarios
slides.notes: Real-world examples of implementing out-of-sequence transactions in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: In real-world scenarios, out-of-sequence transactions often occur due to backdated policy changes or corrections. Handling these requires leveraging PolicyCenter's robust framework to ensure changes are accurately reflected across the policy timeline. Developers need to understand both the technical and business aspects to effectively manage these changes.
slides.ocrText:
Question
What makes a transaction out-of-sequence?
•
•

questionData.question: What makes a transaction out-of-sequence?
questionData.answer: A transaction is out-of-sequence if it is entered after some other bound transaction but has an effective date earlier than the effective date of the first bound transaction. Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Data Model Considerations for OOS Transactions
slides.notes: Understanding the data model entities involved in out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: The Guidewire data model is pivotal in managing out-of-sequence transactions. Entities like PolicyPeriod and Job serve as the foundation for tracking changes. Developers must understand how these entities relate and interact to maintain data integrity and ensure seamless integration of OOS transactions.
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What makes a transaction out-of-sequence?
•
•
A transaction is out-of-sequence if it is entered after some other bound transaction but
has an effective date earlier than the effective date of the first bound transaction.
Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Customizing OOS Transaction Handling
slides.notes: Opportunities for customization in handling out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: Guidewire PolicyCenter offers extensive customization options for handling out-of-sequence transactions. By tailoring the system to meet specific business needs, developers can enhance the handling of these transactions. This might involve Gosu scripting or modifying PCF files to better manage the unique requirements of OOS scenarios.
slides.ocrText:
Question
Can a submission be out-of-sequence? Why or why not?
•
•

questionData.question: Can a submission be out-of-sequence? Why or why not?
questionData.answer: Can a submission be out-of-sequence? Why or why not? No, a submission can never be out-of-sequence. A submission creates a policy and therefore must be the first transaction that can be issued against a policy. You cannot have transactions effective earlier than the policy's creation date. Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Integration Patterns for OOS Transactions
slides.notes: Exploring integration patterns that support out-of-sequence transaction handling.
slides.narration: Effective handling of out-of-sequence transactions often involves integration with external systems. By utilizing integration patterns like web services or batch processing, developers can ensure that all changes are synchronized across systems. This alignment is crucial for maintaining data consistency and policy accuracy.

slides.notes: User interface considerations for presenting out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: The user interface plays a critical role in managing out-of-sequence transactions. Clear UI patterns help users understand the sequence of changes and any potential conflicts. Developers should focus on creating intuitive interfaces that guide users through the resolution process, enhancing the overall user experience.

slides.narration: Gosu scripting is a powerful tool for resolving conflicts in out-of-sequence transactions. By writing custom scripts, developers can automate conflict resolution based on predefined business logic. This approach not only improves efficiency but also ensures that policies remain consistent and accurate.

slides.title: Best Practices for OOS Transaction Management
slides.notes: Key best practices for managing out-of-sequence transactions effectively.
slides.narration: Managing out-of-sequence transactions requires adherence to best practices, such as maintaining a clear understanding of effective dates and leveraging PolicyCenter's built-in capabilities. By following these practices, developers can ensure that policy changes are handled smoothly, minimizing disruptions and maintaining data integrity.

slides.notes: Identifying and overcoming common challenges in managing out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: Out-of-sequence transactions present several challenges, such as managing conflicting changes and maintaining policy accuracy. By understanding these challenges, developers can proactively address them through strategic planning and robust system configuration. This ensures that the policy lifecycle remains seamless and uninterrupted.

By learning from real-world scenarios, developers can apply similar approaches in their implementations.

slides.notes: Exploring advanced techniques for handling complex out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: For complex out-of-sequence transactions, advanced techniques such as data mapping and custom validation rules can be employed. These techniques allow developers to handle intricate scenarios with precision, ensuring that all policy changes are accurately reflected and conflicts are minimized.

slides.title: Troubleshooting OOS Transaction Issues
slides.notes: Effective troubleshooting strategies for resolving issues with out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: Troubleshooting out-of-sequence transaction issues requires a methodical approach. By analyzing transaction logs and understanding data flow, developers can identify root causes and implement solutions. This proactive troubleshooting ensures that policy changes are applied correctly and efficiently.

Staying informed about these trends is key to maintaining a competitive edge in policy administration.

slides.title: Key Takeaways from OOS Transactions
slides.notes: Summarizing key points and insights from the session on out-of-sequence transactions.
slides.narration: We've covered a lot of ground regarding out-of-sequence transactions in PolicyCenter. Key takeaways include understanding the importance of effective date management, resolving conflicts, and leveraging customization and integration patterns. These insights will equip you to handle OOS transactions effectively, ensuring policy accuracy and integrity.
